English: There is no man more pusillanimous than I when I am planning a campaign. I purposely exaggerate all the dangers and all the calamities that the circumstances make possible. I am in a thoroughly painful state of agitation. This does not keep me from looking quite serene in front of my entourage I am like an unmarried girl laboring with child.

Baroque architecture is a highly decorative and theatrical style which appeared in Italy in the early 17th century and gradually spread across Europe. It was originally introduced by the Catholic Church as a means to combat the Reformation with a new architecture that inspired surprise and awe.

Opera is a form of theatre in which music is a fundamental component and dramatic roles are taken by singers, but is distinct from musical theatre. Opera originated in Italy at the end of the 16th century and soon spread throughout the rest of Europe.
Baroque architecture reached its peak in the High Baroque period, when it was used in churches and palaces in Italy, Spain, Portugal, France, Bavaria, and Austria.

Baroque sculpture is the style of sculpture associated with the period between the 17th and mid 18th centuries. In Baroque sculpture, groups of figures assumed new importance, and there was a dynamic movement and energy of human forms. Baroque sculpture often had multiple viewing angles, and reflected a continuation of the Renaissance move away from the relief sculpture.

François Mansart was a French architect credited with introducing classicism in the Baroque architecture of France. Mansart was highly recognized from the 1620s onward for his skill as an architect, but only the richest could afford to have him work for them, as he would often tear down his structures in order to start building them over again.

Jacques Lemercier was a French architect and engineer, one of the influential trio that included Louis Le Vau and François Mansart, who formed the classicizing French Baroque manner. During 1638 and 1639, Lemercier was appointed the 'premier architecte' charged with supervision of all royal building enterprises in France, and would complete many notable works.

Bohemian glass, also referred to as Bohemian crystal, is glass produced in the regions of Bohemia and Silesia. Bohemia became famous for its beautiful and colorful glass during the Renaissance. Czech glassware became as prestigious as jewellery and was sought-after by the wealthy and the aristocracy.

Rocaille was a french style of exuberant decoration, with an abundance of curves, countercurves, and undulations. Rocaille furniture was heavily loaded with decoration modeled on seashells, flowers, palm leaves, and other elements.

Rococo, or Late Baroque, is an exceptionally ornamental and theatrical style of architecture, art, and decoration. Rococo style began in France in the 1730s as a reaction against the more formal and geometric style of French classicism.

Baroque music is a period of Western classical music from approximately 1600 to 1750 that originated in Western Europe. The Baroque period saw the creation of common-practice tonality, an approach to writing music in which a song or piece is written in a particular key.

Johann Sebastian Bach was a German composer and musician of the Late Baroque period. He is known for instrumental compositions such as the Cella Suites and Brandenburg Concertos, along with keyboard works and vocal music.
